title: get_basedata
text: second function, get_basedata() returns data frame containing information United States’ overseas military bases going back beginning Cold War. basic function return data frame containing country-base observations, along facility’s longitude latitude (available), series binary variables indicating whether facility full military base, smaller lilypad, currently funded site. get_troopdata() function can specify numeric vector COW country codes character vector ISO3C codes specify specific host countries. example, using COW country codes: another using ISO3C codes: Finally, users can also generate country-level counts number U.S. military bases changing country_count argument TRUE. Note using argument also need specify groupvar argument, specifies identifier used generate country-level totals. Though may sound obvious individual country codes may include multiple geographic territories finely parsed using various identifiers. Accepted character strings include “countryname”, “iso3c”, “ccode”. may seem redundant given host argument, provide flexibility users may familiar country codes want spend time trying identify long-form country names.

A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   countryname         ccode iso3c basename   lat    lon  base lilypad fundedsite #>   <chr>               <dbl> <chr> <chr>    <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Ascension Island      200 GBR   Ascensi… -7.95  -14.4     1       0          0 #> 2 BR Indian Ocean Te…   200 GBR   Diego G… -7.32   72.4     1       0          0 #> 3 Canada                 20 CAN   NA       56.1  -106.      0       1          0 #> 4 Canada                 20 CAN   Argenti… 47.3   -54.0     1       0          0 #> 5 Germany               255 DEU   Amberg   49.4    11.9     1       0          0 #> 6 Germany               255 DEU   USAG An… 49.3    10.6     1       0          0 hostlist.char <- c("CAN", "GBR", "PRI")  baseexample <- get_basedata(host = hostlist.char, country_count = FALSE) hostlist <- c(20, 200, 255, 645)  baseexample <- get_basedata(host = hostlist, country_count = TRUE, groupvar = "ccode") #> Warning: Must specify grouping variable when using country_count. #> Warning: group var must equal 'countryname', 'ccode', or 'iso3c'.  head(baseexample) #> # title: get_builddata
text: Users can call get_builddata() returns data frame containing geocoded location-project-year military construction data. basic arguments function compared previous functions. primary difference data currently available countries years Department Defense publicly discloses spending figures 2008 2019. Note also many observations included contain amounts, disclose location names information. base data can build cool maps using construction data. can also size points according amount spending associated particular location, adding additional details maps figures.
code: hostlist <- c(200, 255, 211)  buildexample <- get_builddata(host = hostlist, startyear = 2008, endyear = 2019) #> Warning: Be advised that the data include unspecified locations, as well as 0 #> or negative spending values. #> Warning: Spending values are in thousands of current US dollars.  head(buildexample) #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   countryname    ccode iso3c  year location        lat    lon spend_construction #>   <chr>          <dbl> <chr> <dbl> <chr>         <dbl>  <dbl>              <dbl> #> 1 United Kingdom   200 GBR    2008 Royal Air Fo…  52.4  0.518               1800 #> 2 United Kingdom   200 GBR    2008 Royal Air Fo…  52.4  0.518              15500 #> 3 United Kingdom   200 GBR    2008 Menwith Hill…  54.8 -2.70               10000 #> 4 United Kingdom   200 GBR    2008 Menwith Hill…  54.8 -2.70               31000 #> 5 United Kingdom   200 GBR    2009 Royal Air Fo…  52.4  0.518              71828 #> 6 United Kingdom   200 GBR    2009 Royal Air Fo…  52.4  0.518               7400 library(ggplot2)  map <- ggplot2::map_data("world") basepoints <- troopdata::get_builddata(host = NA, startyear = 2009, endyear = 2019)   buildmap <- ggplot() +   geom_polygon(data = map, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group), fill = "gray80", color = "white", size = 0.1) +   geom_point(data = basepoints, aes(x = lon, y = lat, size = spend_construction), color = "purple", alpha = 0.4) +   coord_equal(ratio = 1.3) +   theme_void() +   theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 15)) +   labs(title = "Locations of U.S. military construction spending, 2009-2019",        size = "Spending Amount")   buildmap

title: get_troopdata
text: default get_troopdata() function returns aggregate sum active duty military personnel. original DMDC reports often include disaggregated figures, separate counts branch military. branch argument allows users specify whether like receive aggregate sum branches disaggregated figures branch. argument can take three values: TRUE, FALSE, vector branch names. case _ad suffix variable name indicates “Active Duty” numbers given branch. Note total necessarily equal sum individual branches. function returns maximum annual value branch. cases quarterly values reported, sum total may come one quarter individual branch values may come another quarter. can also include disaggregated data national guard reserve personnel, well DoD civilians. numbers generally reported recent years, available countries time periods. Later updates include observations earlier time periods available.
code: # Let's get the disaggregated data for the US deployments to Canada and the UK hostlist <- c("Canada", "United Kingdom")  example.branch <- get_troopdata(host = hostlist, branch = TRUE, startyear = 1970, endyear = 2020) #> Warning: Branch data only includes active duty by default. text: recent update also allows users specify fine grained temporal coverage. DMDC reports historically released annual basis, recent years released twice annually even quarterly, get_troopdata() function allows users specify whether like receive quarterly data annual data. quarters argument allows users specify whether like receive quarterly data annual data. argument can take two values: TRUE FALSE default FALSE. user opts return quarterly data, function return month quarter columns addition year. Note every quarter corresponds quarterly report every country. cases quarterly value may 0 rather NA. Additionally, Army reported branch data several recent quarters 2022 2023 due internal personnel management changes. Accordingly aggregate totals quarters may lower expected available. use full country names. See! Neat!

This preserves #> continuity across time periods as guard and reserve data are not reported prior #> to 2000s. #> Warning: Some service branches do not report data for all quarters. See the #> following note from December, 2022, June 2023, and March 2023 DMDC reports: #> 'The Army is converting its Integrated Personnel and Pay System (IPPS-A) and so #> the Army did not provide military personnel data for end-of-June 2023.'  head(example.quarters) #> # A tibble: 6 × 14 #>   countryname  year month   quarter ccode iso3c region troops_ad army_ad navy_ad #>   <chr>       <dbl> <chr>     <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <chr>      <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 Canada       2015 Decemb…       4    20 CAN   North…        91       3       0 #> 2 Canada       2015 June          2    20 CAN   North…       153       8       0 #> 3 Canada       2015 March         1    20 CAN   North…       144       8       0 #> 4 Canada       2015 Septem…       3    20 CAN   North…       146       8       0 #> 5 Canada       2016 Decemb…       4    20 CAN   North…       141       6       0 #> 6 Canada       2016 June          2    20 CAN   North…       146       6       0 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: air_force_ad <dbl>, marine_corps_ad <dbl>, #> #   coast_guard_ad <dbl>, space_force_ad <dbl>
